commentBody: Nice, clean full but a tad too easy for a Saturday. On days like this I miss the pre-2020 Fridays and Saturdays that were/still are a solid workout and feel more satisfying.
Quick solve for a Saturday puzzle. Was stuck on 1A (of all things) which I kept seeing as a noun or verb instead of an adjective.

I'm amused that I put married for SAIDIDO. Right idea, wrong word...

I like that I didn't need to look anything up; any fill I didn't know (like HAINES and SUNROSE) was solvable by the crosses, and it all fell neatly into place in well under average time for Saturday. 

My only complaint is that now I want bacon...

I was in my Saturday puzzle armor and ready to do battle. Turns out I didn‚Äôt need to get dressed at all. For a Saturday it was just a bit too pedestrian unless I am getting smarter which is debatable
Felt like a really tough 12 minute solve. Was conceivable SLOP/PLOT was right in the NE, so took a while to work that out
Lots of swings and misses for me in the NW corner, but I finally cracked it. Great Saturday puzzle - crunchy and clever but not impossible.

Well crafted crossword, but not sufficiently difficult for a Saturday. This crossword is more like a Wednesday.  Level of difficulty is important for a progressively more difficult weekly series. I'm surprised Will Shortz approved it for Saturday, but in all fairness, maybe he didn't have anything else to select.
Glop?

I felt Saturday smart on this one.  Was it that extra sugar intake right before the puzzle?

SE section sent me up the wall for a while.

Nice puzzle Shaun.

"Sometimes even now, when I'm feeling lonely and beat
I drift back in time and I find my feet
Down on Mainstreet"

I almost never solve a Friday puzzle without checking this column but did it on this one. Probably a sign that it‚Äôs too easy for a Friday, but I‚Äôm definitely not complaining. I expected ‚Äútitled‚Äù one to be a commoner who‚Äôs ennobled but was surprised to see homeowner work. I had fun with it.

I liked the number of long entries. But this is a very segmented, walled-off grid, and I got annoyed that the two words you really needed to bridge the gap were, by far, the most obscure names in the puzzle. Not even having most of the crosses was a guarantee.
That NW corner would not let me in, repeatedly slapping me and laughing, and I had to go to the column for PEEPER. Kudos Shaun.

Said the horticulturalist to his plants, "I mist you."

(From the play "Mulch a Dew About Nothing")
Well, this puzzle wasn‚Äôt quite as easy for me as for some early posters here, but I done did it. (Eddie we miss you!)

This was great fun, with lots of "Oh right!"s while I solved, and plenty of tips 'o the hat to the constructor.  Everything worked so well, and even though I was stymied sometimes, I was never tempted to ask Prof. Google for any help at all.

Thank you, Shaun Philips, for a beautifully crafted puzzle.  More please.

Jeeper, creeper
Got blinded by one PEEPER!

Fun solve, missed by a letter.
Wonderful sentiment from Shaun Phillips in his constructor notes. We're all lucky to be here.

Happy for the chance to fight another grid, thanks to Will and the NYT team.

If I was playing the scheduling game, I would have switched the Friday and Saturday puzzles this week.
Whatever the day, this one was very much in my wheelhouse and it was a fun solve. 
Thanks Shaun.
Nice clean puzzle, with just a dab of glop in the NEcorner.

A real, honest workout. The NW was roughest for me.

Good stuff!

For me it was a pretty quick solve.

Looking up SUNROSE I found that it probably refers to Helianthemum which is another word for Rock Rose. To me they resemble Portulaca aka Moss Rose or Purslane which is one of my absolute favorite summer flowers to have in pots outside with the same small brilliant flowers (although they are in different families). Google says Helianthemum are hardy in US zones 6-8 so maybe I could get away with them as a perennial in Tennessee ü§î

A beautiful-looking grid.
Engaging clues and fill.
Funny and lovely constructor notes.
All around delightful. Thank you, Mr. Phillips!
Close Encounter led me astray!

I do not time myself.  My goal is to solve crosswords with no lookups. So for me, streaks are important. Right now my streak is at 44.  Sometimes it takes me as much as two hours to solve a puzzle, but I don't care about how long it takes.  I care about figuring it out with no lookups.  That's the real brain exercise that I think is important.

Me and my girlfriend struggled with this puzzle. Not due to lack of brain power. Purely because the hints were atrocious and they made absolutely zero sense. She is taking the MCAT so i know she is more than capable. And i work with rocket launchers. So i am capable too. This puzzle is sub-par. Have a great night.

Heh, as a few others have also said, PEEPER was the last to fall. I thought maybe [Baby blue, perhaps] referred to a word that was blue, as in risqu√©, and also in baby talk (hey, we had a whole puzzle devoted to buttocks earlier this week, after all!), so I had the last letter wrong for quite a while. It didn‚Äôt help that the resulting crossing thus ended up being ESTEe, which didn‚Äôt quite make sense with that down clue, but it‚Äôs such common fill, and I thought there was a chance that there was some sort of devious Saturday misdirection going on where lateral thinking could make half of a cosmetics brand name a ‚Äúcompound‚Äù of some sort. Maybe I just have juvenile mind, and somebody needs to tell me to GO FLY A KITE.
A fun one. Had a fast start. Then I got stumped with the left side a bit with words such as PEEPER, SUNROSE, and CHIPBOARD. Still clocked in a little over an hour without any lookups.

This puzzle was humbling for me -- arC, Over, yokoono, landOWNER, cLoseENCOUNTER, mArrIed, fee, and wAwaS (although that was more desperate than the others) were wrong guesses that kept things painful, while feldspar and headhunters were just guesses that didn't have enough letters. All in all, it took longer than Thursday and Friday combined and four times longer than my Saturday best. Phew.

No complaints about the puzzle, though. Thanks for the workout, Shaun!

After a brutal Thursday and a fair but tough Friday, nice to go easy on my eyesight and not have to stare at a phone screen for more than 20 minutes. Definitely on the constructor‚Äôs wavelength, frequency and amplitude.

I tried to solve unaided, but it turned out to be impossible. I was able to complete the strip running from NE to SW almost on my own, with just two lookups for DODGERS and HAINES, but the NW and SE corners defeated me.

To deal with those I looked up the ending of the song title - I was missing A KITE. I saw Mary Poppins, once, probably 35 years ago, and I remember nothing about it. It's just not really part of Polish culture.

I've never heard of FREESTONE - I suspected what it might be once I got FREES___, but I looked up the ending to make sure.

MAIN ST stumped me. The "on signs" part of the clue misled me - in Europe it is common for a symbol of concentric circles to represent town center on roadsigns, and I fixated on iconography rather than words. Btw, our streets generally have fancy names, not practical ones like in the US. Thus few settlements have a Main St, at all - it will often be Warszawska (Warsaw St) outside Warsaw.

I also looked up PAC and CRISPED. As for bacon, strips of it were unknown over here before 1989. We have always consumed pork belly, of course, but usually smoked, then diced and fried, as an element of sauces or with scrambled eggs. Rashers came with democracy and market economy, but they are still used only occasionally, like in burgers or to wrap dates or tiny sausages for party snacks.

I liked the puzzle and its clueing. It was simply too hard in places for me as a Polish non-native speaker of English - not a complaint at all, just fact.

SROUNDS, PLOT, CLAPBOARD, LETSGOFORARIDE, DROVELULU (that's a thing, right?) got me beaten down for so long. But with quasi-perseverance, a dollop of good luck and a couple of look-ups (apparently, she wants to fly a kite... who knew? ü§∑üèæ‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è), I completed it just before the 1hr mark.

I‚Äôve been doing this for awhile, but it‚Äôs still rare for me to get through a Saturday without a lookup. Today was no exception. Googling the Mary Poppins song gave me all the leverage I needed to get going, and I was excited by how nicely everything fell into place‚Ä¶until the top left corner did me in. Argh, PEEPER.  Oh well, blue star for the win!
A quick Saturday for me done in 16 mins. But GLOP? I just don‚Äôt hear that used at all although Google suggests it is. I had SLOP for a long time which stymied me in the northeast corner.
Started off with LETS GO FLY A KITE,  but that was about it, typical Saturday puzzle, needed lots of help, but I don‚Äôt mind.

Speaking of PEEPERs, didn't see the two kites until Caitlin pointed them out -- way over my head!  

Sorry.
Anyone else first think of "tariff-free" for 1D?
Nice puzzle. Quite easy for a Saturday (for me) but the cluing was intelligent, without no junk and only a single abbreviation. Thank you! More like this, please.
NW corner was tough. Probably because I went from CARDBOARD to CLIPBOARD to CHIPBOARD. Also had LANDOWNER and CHANCE ENCOUNTER. Nice Saturday puzzle though!

Hard to define indeed.  I always think CHARISMA = smarm, but that's probably just my cynicism showing.

Overall, a nice puzzle, but I think the cluing OTTO have been toughened up a bit for a Saturday.

Nuts! Would have had an excellent Saturday effort (for me) had I not overconfidently checked my 24D  answer early on - "shoved down the throat of" . Had FO..... and finished it with FORCEDFED. A clever and deliberate feint by the constructor, I wonder?

Otherwise, no look-ups and a smooth 30 minute ride to the finish. Excellent puzzle.

Yowser, that's an intimidating grid. Oceans of white space.

Looks like thunderstorms all day long for us, so no telling when I'll get back on-line. Ye olde desktoppe compewter gets unplugged whenever there's lightning around.

Actually surprised that so many found this one unusually easy for a Saturday. Wasn't all that easy for me (hi suejean) and had to look some things up, but managed to get through it. There were a number of nice 'aha' moments when I had enough crosses for something to finally dawn on me. Puzzle find today is one that I still find quite puzzling. A Sunday from May 18, 2008 by Brendan Emmett Quigley with the title "Pinball Wizard." Some of what I assume were theme answers - all of which were straightforwardly clued: BONUSQUESTIONS ROLLOVERBEETHOVEN SPECIALRELATIVITY DRAINBOARDS JACKPOTJUSTICE FLIPPERANDERSON (okay that one I sort of get) Here's the Xword Info link. Somebody explain it if you can figure it out: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=5/18/2008&g=15&d=D I'm done. ...
itfactor for CHARISMA. Way off üò≠

@All the Regulars

(I wrote the following reply in the thread started by Mikey Palmar.  I need some feedback about the technical issue we've been having, to see if it's been corrected.  I said:)


I just replied to Teresa, not Mikey, and it showed up for me when I refreshed the page.

(This one is a reply to Mikey.)

Can you all see the reply just above that I made to Teresa?
Not the toughest Saturday by any means but I don‚Äôt think cheap as the answer to budget was the best of clues.
Nice puzzle, though the correct answer to [Like American bacon but not Canadian] is Delicious.

Grid looked so scary!

But this one was was like standing
atop a *huge* hill, fresh with white snow,
starting slowly and then,
wheeeeeeeee!
careening down that puppy with exhilaration.

Loved it.

Thank you Shaun!

And this weekend, to all the mothers,
stepmothers, grandmothers, those who
hope to have a child, those who are celebrating 
the moms in their lives,
Happy Mother‚Äôs Day.

But also- to those who are missing their mother,
didn‚Äôt get to keep them for as long as they‚Äôd wished,
or didn‚Äôt get the mom they deserved -
I do hope someone stepped in and
made you feel safe and loved.

Happy Saturday all!
Nice one! Really pleased that I stuck with it and had no lookups!!! Every word counted. Just kept at it and got everything! Puzzled by DARNERS until I was done & read Wordplay - Eek!

I‚Äôm mostly here to say that Canadian chip board is crispy and delicious, and a great source of your daily fibre.

I didn‚Äôt see the kites until reading the column.
A good puzzle. No cheap glop.
Not all Nordics are natives of Scandinavia.

Good crossword with few general knowledge clues and most of those long enough for me to have plenty of crossers. I got the top right to bottom left diagonal pretty quickly but eventually decided that I had to blank out some or all of a lot of guesses in the other corners (hard board, land owner, forced fed and, yes, ester and Alien encounter) New guesses at the crossers let me know which words to reinstate and then I could complete in a better than average time.

Solved this one easily enough, but didn't really enjoy it. Found a lot of the fill rather forced and dull: IMISSED, NODDEDOFF, HUNGERSFOR, DROVENUTS, TURNITON, DUETO, FOISTEDON. Suppose I'm just not a fan of lengthening entries by appending prepositions to them.

That said, there were some interesting *words* here too: CHARISMA, HOLISTIC, RECRUITERS.

Took me way too long to recall the "Mary Poppins" tune, despite the clue being almost too helpful for a Saturday. Unfamiliar with FREESTONE as clued, though again the clue seemed almost "definitional" in nature. Would "Peach type" have been too easy?

RVTRIPS is an interesting string of letters, as is MAINST.

Most puzzling for me is why OTTO is an apt name for a NASCAR driver. Still trying to solve that one ...

"Mary Poppins" was the first movie I ever saw!  (Or, perhaps I should say "the first movie I can remember seeing.) It's still one of my favorites, so 7-Down was a gimme for me...although I was amazed that such a long title would fit in the grid!  Five words and 15 letters.

"With your feet on the ground
You're a bird in a flight
With your fist holding tight
To the string of your kite."

I realized today that after 40 some years in Qu√©bec I've never eaten Canadian bacon, and I can't remember seeing it in the stores either. When people say bacon (same word in English or French) they mean bacon, like what you get in the US.

If you want a really high-fat Canadian pork product, go to a Qu√©bec sugar shack in the spring and get "oreilles de Christ" or "oreilles de crisse" --  slices of salted pork lard, boiled and then fried to a golden brown. Cover with maple syrup to offset the saltiness.

A tough solve, even by Saturday standards‚Ä¶especially the NW. I would have preferred to finish without looking anything up but I have a shift at the food pantry in an hour, so I broke down and looked up one (14A) and it was enough to break the dam, though I had to finish by guessing what for me was a natick at 27A/29D).

I don't know why the Saturday NYT grids intimidate me, they just do. Today's 34A‚Äôd me to no end.

FOIST? Definitely a foist for me, not familiar with that term, at all.

Funny, the 7D put the Von Trapp‚Äôs ‚ÄúFavorite Things‚Äù into my head. Nothing to do with Mary Poppins whatsoever, but our music teachers drilled all these songs into our head. (Hey, just found a use for FOIST).

29A brought back the old wives tale of avoiding dragonflies, or they‚Äôll‚Ä¶ ah, you know. That was one way to get ‚Äúus kids‚Äù to keep our mouths shut during church (unlike Layne Staley‚Äôs ‚ÄúMan in a Box‚Äù).

I‚Äôve been a professional geologist for over thirty years and never seen or heard the term freestone as defined here. I know it as a term to distinguish rocky rivers from limestone streams. Learning!

Wowie Zowie (as the NYT puzzle once declared)--that NW corner was UTTER cruelty (or so Shaun Phillips hoped!)  I cannot explain how I got it.  
For some reason I had OWED at 26A (in tiny letters in case I needed to erase it.)  I entered ESTER at 3D early on, and took it out, only to reverse course down the road.
PLYWOOD comes in sheets, but the fit was wrong.  Some kind of BOARD....BEADBOARD?  Abandon that one and move on.
LANDOWNER?  Take out LAND.
Put in ALIEN; take out ALIEN.
CHIP! CHIPBOARD.  We don't call it that, but I can't think of the term.... nonetheless, that entry broke the rest of the logjam!!

Elsewhere, I wanted ANEMONE for the brightly-colored flowers.  SUN ROSE????
ASTI is a wine *region* but "a wine"??
Oh, who cares?  I cracked this sucker like an egg.  One with a hard shell.

[First contact]=ALIEN ENCOUNTER is an iffy clue. After all, it only counts as a "first" contact, when it's the, well, first. I remember my first abduction by Little Grays, when I was eleven, back in June of 1974: I was in a vacant lot at the end of Main St., peacefully flying a kite, when suddenly, I was struck by a powerful energy beam, and sucked up into an alien saucer. I was chilled to the bones!

Little did I know then that it was the first of a series of experiments, conducted on regular ten-year intervals: in June of 1984, then an undergraduate at college, I felt the same beam of energy, the same pull.  "Again? For real!?!" I cried!

By the third, in 1994, the journey to Zeta Reticula was no more intimidating than an RV trip.  By the fourth, in 2004, I was saying "I missed you!" when they beamed me up, and "So long" when they dropped me back.
I done did this puzz

I don‚Äôt often see the constructor chime in on this board and perhaps that is for good cause (allowing an air of mystery, or remaining a safe distance from criticism, perhaps) but I thought I might check in this time and sincerely thank each of you for sharing your thoughts and experiences with this puzzle. Whether you loved or hated it, you solved it, and I take that as a blessing. It‚Äôs an honor to be able to contribute a crossword that gave many of you a bit of fun, and maybe a few fits. 

One clue idea of mine that didn‚Äôt make the editorial filter was ‚ÄúCause for an investigational probe?‚Äù at 12D. Crass, maybe, but I thought amusing. Alas, Star Trek: First Contact, is one of my favorite films, so Will & team blessed this puzzle with that particular PG-rating fix.

Don‚Äôt forget to call your mother (or tell a motherly figure in your life that you appreciate them) tomorrow (and every day)!
great puzzle!

Ah  movies. The first on I saw was Rodan (big bird destroys most of Japan). My Aunt took us, she was our favorite.

My view of the Sound of Music was altered when I lived in Vermont and learned the past and present antics of the Von Trapps.

I am one with Mean Old Lady. ASTI is a wine region as opposed to a Wine.

Nice one Shaun
Loved this grid! It was really on my wavelength compared to most Saturdays and I had a personal best for solve time.

So TIL that the dragonflies I call hawkers are also called darners. I have to say I prefer the common BrE name.
A few unknowns, including that long Mary Poppins reference, but enough solid crossing fill to get me through.
Last to fall was PEE_ERS, neither "baby blues" nor "peepers" being common usage for me, and the crossing clue about bacon being impenetrable.

Yes, of course, there weren't many options for the mystery square, but when I blanked on it I shelved it until the end.

To Steve L, et al
Re the posting problem
My response to MOL's main post just below does not show up unless I employ the time stamp.

As I worked on the puzzle I found a various clues quite easy. I said wow, this is easy for Saturday. Especially since I didn't get either Thursday or Friday. I came in at about 60% of my average. It was a fun puzzle. I can take easy any day.

As a racing enthusiast and former finance bro, I'm embarrassed to admit I didn't know that RACE is the ticker symbol for Ferrari. On a related note, there are actually no NASCAR drivers with the first name OTTO, as "apt" as it may be.
Diabolical that the other famous musical Impressionist also fit at 17A: WEIRD AL.
Easier than the usual Saturday puzzle, but I got it without cheating, so I can't complain.
Proper names were not obscure people, except for "Haines." I'm happy to solve without having to look things up, with self-contained puzzles like this one.
I echo Shaun--so great to have Will back and many thanks to Joel and the rest for keeping us going.
Now _there's_ a different grid pattern!
So much fun with this one ‚Äî lovely grid, sparkling fill. Thanks Shaun.
Not sure I've ever heard GLOP for gross food. I've heard of SLOP though, which is what you feed to pigs.

I had "Favorite Things" for the Mary Poppins song, thinking that song's title omitted the "My". It sent me down the wrong track for the longest time. 

Whoever clued the rhyming lyrics  "With tuppence for paper and strings/ You can have your own set of wings" - be it constructor or editor - is a sadist :)

Great puzzle.
Started scary, but I finished strong. It was a fun puzzle that made me think!
All round good puzzle IMHO.
I was definitely on the same wavelength today; this one flowed for me like a wonderful dance.
"Let's go fly a kite"  was my entr√©e into the puzzle.   Helps that we did a dance to it in a ballet recital as a teen.  Had kite props, of course.

Enjoyed this a lot.  All but the NW were easy but I might never have gotten that without the column's PEEPER. I resisted PAC for no good reason other than I guess donating invokes  non-profits not politicians to me, though we do give to both.
  Can't Canadian bacon be crispy? What would really have worked there is MARBLED, though it's probably lucky that I couldn't recall that word at the time.
And DARNERS is JUST NOT FAIR, especially given the cross AND the fact that a plainer clue was ready to hand. If, as the constructor suggests, Shortz came up with that, then POOHIE on him. I kept wanting DARTERS but no, SONTETS is not an alternative poetic form. And sure, if you have H_INES then A is the most likely.  But still.
Only gripe is that sun roses are native to South Africa and not the Mediterranean. This threw me off as a botanist. Oh well!

Today's ear worm, obviously, is LETSGOFLYAKITE. If you don't know it, don't look it up. It really is an ear worm; I'm sure to still be singing it at bedtime.

But I enjoyed this Saturday puzzle that took me a while to get through, but with no look ups! Go, me!

I had to smile when I solved GLOP--my mom was not a great cook, and often when I asked what was for dinner, she said GLOP.    That could mean any type of meat and veg casserole, or bean dish, or spaghetti.  Miss you, mom, this Mother's Day weekend!

And the Mary Poppins lyric--that was one of the first movies my mom took us to.

Feeling happy on a Saturday morning!
Caitlin, thank you for the link to the fascinating article on dragonflies!

Best kind of Saturday solve for me. About a quarter hour in, I started feeling stuck, but each pass through the puzzle yielded at least one or two new letters, enough to keep hope alive. As I was approaching my normal time for Saturdays, I still had dismaying expanses of open ground in both the NW and SE and thought this was going to be a long one. But then in less than a half minute both quadrants fell and suddenly I was done.

What did it for me was finally letting go of FOrced in the SE, and then, feeling newly confident, realizing that what I needed in the NW was not to imagine watching a cat, but imagine _being_ a cat.

Now to see what the rest of you think. I'll admit, I've begun to find these comments more intimidating than the puzzles. Although there are always jewels that make the intimidation (mostly) worth it.
Hmm, my comment is being held up for some reason. Can't think what the offending word might be.
That was fun, but surprisingly easy for me for a Saturday!

What an intimidating start to this puzzle! So much empty space, but then at least a reference to the International Swimming Hall of Fame to get us started (/s). Really wanted SLOP instead of GLOP, but was saved by 13A being straightforward and making a strong argument against the S. This was a really well put together puzzle, it came together with little bits here and there adding up to steady progress.

The NW corner sent me to the Column. PlyBOARD was one letter short for 10D, and smokED was too short for 1D. But Caitlin refused to offer anything but PEEPER for 20A. Maybe I'll try again when I finish Spelling Bee, Wordle, and today's email. ___PBOARD? ____PED bacon? STRIPPED didn't fit.
I had close encounter instead of ALIENENCOUNTER in the NW for far too long.

TIL that PASSEDOUT and NODDEDOFF have the same number of letters (and the O from LETSGOFLYAKITE in the same position).

NW took me a while. WALLBOARD, ALLINONE (for HOLISTIC), CLOSEENCOUNTER, etc. Finally worked them all out.
This one was fun, and I got a new idea for a plant for the yard!  Win win.
For an LAer, DODGERS was the gimme that turned despair into eventual victory.
Had some fun misdirects without being overly difficult! NW was the trickiest part for me.

I gave out a little gasp when I saw the empty grid, thinking this was going to be fun - and I was right. It started slowly until I hit LET'S GO FLY A KITE, which was a gimme. At the end, the NW took some fiddling. I had ALLOT for 1A, but it didn't fit with PAC, which seemed correct. CHEAP finally came to mind and things fell into place after that. Changing HOINES to HAINES gave me the happy music. This was a delightful Saturday workout. Thanks for the fun!

userDisplayName: Only As Good As The Broth
commentBody: My mother, since passed, sang the song "Let's go fly a kite" when I was small child. I had completely forgotten that song until this puzzle. Then, upon realizing the answer, I could hear her voice singing the tune to me. Thank you for that memory trigger.
Just a really good puzzle.  Challenging for me, but got it no lookups.
Perfect Sat challenge. NW section really tripped me up.
Not a bad puzzle, and for once my guesses paid off.
Good puzzle!

Nice puzzle, easier than a few of the recent ones.

I enjoyed the tricky clues.
At first, seemed as easy as flying a kite, but then it became an alien enounter...but ultimately, I said I did it!

When I was a kid, there was a certain type of dragonfly we called sewing bugs.  If they were around, you had to make sure you kept your mouth open so they wouldn‚Äôt sew it up (similar to what is referenced in Caitlin‚Äôs column).  It was this memory that helped me fill in 29A (with my mouth open) after having filled a couple of crosses.
My very first no-lookup Saturday EVER!!!!  I want to thank this entire community for giving me the hope and endurance to keep at a puzzle even when it seems impossible and inscrutable.
That was tuffffff but fair

My childhood was far from perfect, but nobody ever suggested that a dragonfly might sew up my mouth. For that I am eternally grateful!

I did not find this easy as so very many of you seem to have. Perhaps it's because I never knew the fear of dragonflies... or because I never liked Mary Poppins and the only thing I could think of was a spoonful of sugar.  

GLOP didn't help either! üòÜ

But for me, it was not quite as hard as yesterday or Thursday's puzzles were, though it was equally enjoyable, and I'm proud that I  accomplished all three of them without any assistance, when for me they were all hard.  Huzzah! 

The grid design somehow intimidated me at first and it took a while to get anything really going, but I'm very glad to have kept at it! And to somehow have retained the memory of MLB teams. I was super into the Milwaukee Brewers when I was a kid, but sort of fell out of it as I got older.

Lastly, I sincerely hope that I will forget the image of dragonflies sewing up mouths....  I mean, let me forget that thought instead of why I walked into a certain room, for Pete's SAKE! But no, that's not how my brain works and now I already know the theme of tonight's nightmares. Thanks a lot, Shaun!!  üòÇ  

(But for real, thanks! Very enjoyable puzzle and lovely comments!!)
Just went back to see the kites in this beautifully constructed grid. Wonderful!
Unbalanced puzzle, some very easy clues mixed with some absolute clunkers, GLOP chief among them. This one wasn't for me
Can't.Get.The.Song.Out.Of.My.Head

Why all the animosity towards GLOP?

My undergraduate college eschewed fraternities, but it had rooming and dining "co-ops," which filled the same sociological niche. Several of them were dogmatic about serving organic, vegetarian meals ("vegan" wasn't a thing, yet), and often the entree would be a casserole based on (brown) rice or (whole-grain) pasta, which was, let me say it, pure glop.

To this day, "gloppy"--as in "gloppy rice"--is the highest term of praise I can give!
What a great puzzle! Something about this one was just so satisfying to put together.
18 minutes, no lookups, trusted my gut on some of them and it paid off.
Too easy for Saturday. I literally finished this one even faster than Tuesday this week (barely, but still). This should have maybe been a Wednesday or Thursday at most. Not a Saturday.
Easier than Friday‚Äôs, and I‚Äôm not complaining. üôÇ
there had to have been a better clue for DARNERS

Lovely puzzle, tough but fair. Thanks, Shaun Phillips and the whole team. 
The Thursday puzzle (surprisingly) and yesterday‚Äôs puzzle seemed pretty tough to me, and this one was still a challenge, but with more ways in. I certainly found it more accessible and entertaining.
I have definitely seen DARNERS, beautiful little dragonflies, but don‚Äôt recall hearing that name for them. It was quite gruesome hearing about the tale that they sew children‚Äôs lips shut. Ick. 
Wishing you all a safe and enjoyable weekend.
Really struggled in the SE for some reason. Had to leave and come back. Fun puzzle overall, not a lot of objectionable fill or cluing & a pretty grid

There appears to be a misapprehension that glop and slop are the same thing. Where I come from, they are not.

Slop: a pail of kitchen scraps for the hogs. Akin to today's compost. Not suitable for human consumption.

Glop: Fit for human consumption, but having a gloppy texture, as with overcooked oatmeal.

When sitting down to eat, I might have commented to my mother that something was gloppy, but never in a million years would I have said it was slop. Not if I wanted to live to tell the tale.

@Andrzej

It is interesting how different countries have different ways of marking their downtowns.  I was totally clueless in Rome until someone pointed out the street names on the sides of buildings.  Not sure if all of Rome was like that, or if it's like that now.

The most lost I've ever been was in Venice.  I was young then, and adept at maps, having more less rolled through Rome, Florence, and (later) London.  But Venice was my Waterloo.

I swear at one point I finally had to conclude I was diametrically opposite of where I thought I was.  

Not too long after that I got lost in Mexico City.  

I mostly stay at home now.

Oh, and the reason I struggled in the NW was because I confidently entered landOWNER there. In Poland, ownership of homes follows ownership of land. There is no separate title for any building on the land. Since the 1990s it is only possible to separate apartments from their buildings as objects of property rights. So in Poland one has either a title to land or to an apartment. I suppose in the wider sense ones does have a title to any home they own, but my intelligence curbed by familiary with Polish law refused to see it.

@Francis
And some countries don't have a 'downtown' at all! 
As a child we went 'up the town' to where all the shops were. In London the theatres are in the West End, or 'up west.' 
The fashion now in the UK is talk of 'quarters' eg the museum quarter, medieval quarter, jewellery quarter, although some newly built areas have been named recently.

Has been preserved*

Doh.

@Andrzej
In the states it often seems that if a street is named for a person, that person is a politician. If not a politician, a tree or a number. Certainly not an artist, writer, philosopher, or, I don't know, a physicist.  Very different from Europe.

@Andrzej

In the US, a home is normally sold along with the land beneath it, so technically a HOMEOWNER is also a landowner.  But when we speak of a landowner, or more commonly, owning land, we're referring to someone who has title to undeveloped land.  

It would be strange to call someone a landowner who owns a half-acre with a house on it.  Perhaps you might get away with calling a person a landowner if he has a house on a 100-acre property.  

(An acre, about 43,000 square feet, is the area a team of oxen can plow in one day. Supposedly.  I've never tested it.)

@Steve L

Linguistically you're right, of course. To me as a lawyer though titles are about what they relate to under the law, and in Poland it's plots of land and apartments, not buildings. It is legally impossible to have a title to a *home* as such - the "title" to it follows from the title to the land. I'm not saying the clue was bad, at all. I just explained in my post above why I made the mistake, and why it made sense in my mind. It took me forever to change land to HOME because I'm a lawyer.

I will, however, confess to being a big Sandy Koufax fan, so DODGERS was a gimme for me.

@Andrzej

It's difficult to generalize about street names in the United States, because the circumstances vary from town to town. You have cities like Washington, D.C. that had their street grids planned and named in advance. At the other extreme, there are major roads that follow the route of a long-gone deer path from three hundred years ago. You have New Orleans, with its French past. And I once ate breakfast in a small town in New York where everybody, including the UPS driver coming in with a delivery, was speaking Polish. Tucson was once part of Mexico.

The metropolitan area of my city, Atlanta, formed from many small settlements that grew and merged. "Church Street" is a common street name in small towns, so we have maybe a dozen different "Church Streets" scattered throughout the area. Sometimes address follow those of the original town, and the system can change abruptly; you can see an address on one building of "137," but the adjacent building has "5280" on it, because that was where the former town's border was. The map looks a bit like someone soaked some spaghetti in ink and threw it at a piece of paper.

The US is a big place, people from all over the world have settled here, and there's lots of variation.

@The X-Phile

Au contraire, mon fr√®re. The area around ‚Äò‚Äúthe room where it happened‚Äù in Philadelphia is called Old City. And Alexandria, VA has an Old Town neighborhood.

@Steve L
When we lived in NE Ohio, we owned 8 acres and built a house and a barn on the land.  When the annual Balloon Races took place, it was quite common for some of the hot=air balloons to come to Earth on our property.  The chase cars would rush up and someone would hurry to speak with us, then use a walkie-talkie to declare, "We have the LANDOWNER's permission!"  We helped bring the errant balloon to the roadway so the team could deflate and load the gondola and balloon, etc.

@Andrzej

Having lived in quite a few states, I note that geographical street names are common:  River Rd., Water Street, Briarcliff Road, Broadway,...and often Martin Luther King, Jr. Boulevard.  
Army posts (Fort Chaffee, Schofield Barracks) had streets named for prominent generals or sometimes just features of the setting:  Gimlet Gulch, for instance...we lived on Bragg Street once.
Modern city subdivisions quite commonly have a 'theme' --Smoking Oaks neighborhood had Water Oak, Red Oak, etc.  (It often gets cutesy....)

It's not that easy to pigeonhole names....
My sister lived in Toronto on "Avenue Road."  Go figure.

@Andrzej
Some USA street names are good. I was always a bit sad during the 9 years that I lived in Chicago because Goethe Street was not in a convenient neighborhood.  I would have had to learn to pronounce it as GO EETH EE of  course. 
And look up a map of Washington, DC. The East-West streets are in alphabetical order but ALSO:
1. Letters only (no J)
2. one syllable
3. two syllable
4. three syllable
5. four syllable
Upper northwest switched to floral-related

@Steve L

And even Knoxville, TN, has an "Old City" neighborhood.

@Mean Old Lady

@RozzieGrandma There's no J Street in Washington, DC because at the time the grid was devised, I and J were not fully considered separate letters,with J being a variation of I. Some dictionaries had one section for both letters. Apparently, Thomas Jefferson used the monogram T.I. on many of his belongings. https://www.snopes.com/fact-check/no-way-no-jay/ Apparently, by the time the alphabetical streets in Brooklyn were laid out, about a century later, I and J were solidly separate, and therefore there's an Avenue I and an Avenue J there.

@The X-Phile

I understand what these two comments are getting at but I think they both miss the original point  because scandies and nordics are (I think)  non-overlapping sets because of, respectively, Finns and Icelanders.  So, no, not like trees:oaks/maples.

Katie, Careful. "All" may work for Native definition 2. It does not work for 1 or 3. native 2 of 2 noun 1: one born or reared in a particular place 2a: an original or indigenous inhabitant b: something indigenous to a particular locality 3: a local resident especially : a person who has always lived in a place as distinguished from a visitor or a temporary resident https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/native

Reposting for those who can't see the original... Katie, Careful. "All" may work for Native definition 2. It does not work for 1 or 3. native 2 of 2 noun 1: one born or reared in a particular place 2a: an original or indigenous inhabitant b: something indigenous to a particular locality 3: a local resident especially : a person who has always lived in a place as distinguished from a visitor or a temporary resident https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/native

Elon,

(1) Crossword clues/answers are by convention always "some" not "all" propositions (with "some" usually only added early in the week or to avoid absurdity).

Scandinavians:  Norwegians, Swedes, Danes, Icelandics. Some northern European territories  and Greenland, all of which are possessions of one of the above countries, are sometimes included.

Nordics: All of the above, plus Finns.

@Esmerelda
You nay know it as "back bacon" in reference to the part of the pig from which it is cut. American bacon is cut from the belly, which is why it's fattier.

@Esmerelda
Growing up in North Jersey, we ate Taylor ham and eggs for our breakfasts. I don't recall when Canadian bacon came into the scene, but tasty, nonetheless.

@Esmerelda    Bacon in Canada is not the same as the bacon in the US.   When I visit Canada for the Stratford Festival, I ask the diner to make the bacon crispy.   I'm not a fan of limp bacon or fries made soggy with gravy.  "Crisp" is the word.

@Esmerelda
Although I've eaten at a few diners in Montreal and Quebec, I can't remember what you call "Canadian bacon" in Quebecois French--but in anglophone Ontario, it is called "Peameal". (Although both cut from the same part of the porker, and both cured, I suppose one could argue that American "Canadian-style" bacon differs from peameal in that it's not (usually) coated in, well, meal [pea or corn]).

MOL, ASTI is indeed a wine. You may know it by the longer name. Asti (also known as Asti spumante) is a sparkling white Italian wine that is produced throughout southeastern Piedmont, but is particularly focused around the towns of Asti and Alba. Since 1993 the wine has been classified as a denominazione di origine controllata e garantita (DOCG) and as of 2004 was Italy's largest producing appellation. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Asti_wine

By the fifth, in 2014, I was downright comfortable there, checking out the local art scene, running up a tab drinking that cheap glop that passes for Asti on ZR (a tab that I leave for the Reticulan elders to pay;-).

Last year, when I there, I found the real estate market on ZR was particularly favorable, I admit, I even considered settling down permanently on the planet and becoming a Reticulan home owner--a modest ranch of chipboard and freestone, the grounds ringed by concentric decorative moats. Reticulan women possess a strong sexual charisma, and peering deeply into the Baby black peepers of two particularly winsome Reticulan lasses (Reticulan marriages, by tradition, polygamous), named Ann and Ester, I admit I almost said "I do." I can't wait for 2034!
